NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS
Mr. William G. Harley
President, NAEB
DuPont Circle Office Building
1346 Connecticut Avenue, N. W.
Washington 6, D. C.
OFFICE OF THE REGIONAL DIRECTOR
2151 Highland Avenue
Birmingham 5, Alabama
May 8, 1962 MAY 10 1962 ^
I
Dear Bill:
This is to commend you for slogging through another series of Board and com¬
mittee sessions with dignity and accomplishment. Our growing pains are so
evident, but growing we must and do. There were several milestones passed
at the recent sessions which were even more significant than those who parti¬
cipated realized. We survived to progress where we might have recessed and
atrophied. I am still concerned with the matter of formalizing mechanics for
our management level structure. During our executive committee meeting, you
felt that the presentation for such considerations would be fitting and proper
for the President to make to the Board. However, in your comments to the Board,
you gave it rather passing attention. I now request that this matter be given
serious constitutional attention.
Out of six TV Board members, all of whom responded to filling the blank, I am
sending you a composite of their response in addition to their comments to a
number of the questions which could not be answered with a simple "yes" or
"no." You will note that there is unanimous opinion in practically every case
and there is certainly evidenced a feeling for serious attention to the matter of
improving our procedures.
May I suggest that, inasmuch as we are all quite in accord as to the necessity
for most of the recommendations, we proceed with the same and formalize the
acceptance by official act, whether this be a change in by-lawy, constitution,
or Board action. Incidentally, I would like to add that meetings of the executive
committee should have an official record by a secretary as we practice with any
other type of meeting.
I am prompted now to urge that we reconsider the matter of where the NAEB Board
meetings will be held in the future. This question has been of serious concern
for sometime because of our inability to decide when and how long our meetings
shall be held. There has been schedule conflict or at least inconvenience in con
